title: 112_s3413
content: The "Tax Hike Prevention Act of 2012" extends tax relief from 2001 and 2003 until December 31, 2013. It also provides alternative minimum tax relief. The "Tax Hike Prevention Act of 2012" extends tax relief until December 31, 2013, including increased alternative minimum tax exemption amounts for taxable years 2012 and 2013. The Tax Hike Prevention Act of 2012 extends tax relief until December 31, 2013, with amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. SEC. 5. Extension of increased expensing limitations and treatment of certain real property as Section 179 property. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend the dollar limitation and reduction in limitation for Section 179 expensing for the years 2010, 2011, 2012, and 2013. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend the dollar limitation and reduction in limitation for Section 179 expensing for the years 2010, 2011, 2012, and 2013. Subsequent amendments include changing dates from 2012 to 2013, 2013 to 2014, and updating special rules for qualified real property. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend the dollar limitation and reduction in limitation for Section 179 expensing for the years 2010, 2011, 2012, and 2013. Amendments include changing dates from 2012 to 2013 and updating special rules for qualified real property. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. SEC. 6. INSTRUCTIONS FOR TAX REFORM. The Senate Committee on Finance must report legislation within 12 months that simplifies the tax code, repeals the alternative minimum tax, is revenue neutral or results in revenue losses, and stimulates economic growth. The Senate Committee on Finance must report legislation within 12 months that simplifies the tax code, repeals the alternative minimum tax, is revenue neutral or results in revenue losses, and stimulates economic growth. The legislation should apply any increased revenue from economic growth to rate reductions, retain a progressive tax code, and reform corporate taxation with a top tax rate of no more than 25 percent and a competitive territorial tax system.
